results.title: Tango Bar
results.creator_credit: Beco Films, Zaga Films, Juan Carlos Codazzi, Roberto Gandara and Marcos Zurinaga
results.brief_description: Raul Julia stars in this story of a trio of performers who play, sing and dance at the “Tango Bar” in Buenos Aires. The trio are split apart by a revolution in Argentina and reunited after 10 years of exile. Whilst the plot of “Tango Bar” revolves around the story of Pedro (Raul Julia), Elena (Valeria Lynch) and Antonio (Ruben Jaurez), it is primarily a tribute to Tango in Argentina. As they perform their show at the Tango Bar - singing, dancing tango and talking about its history and politics, the film flashes to dance sequences of tango performed at various times in the history of the dance form. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Tango
results.creator_credit: Pandora Cinema, Adela Pictures, Alma Ata International Pictures, Argentina Sono Films, Astrolabio Producciones, Beco Films, Hollywood Partners, Saura Films, Terraplen Producciones, Luis Scalella, Carlos L. Mentasti, Juan Carlos Codazzi and Carlos Saura
results.brief_description: This Argentinian/Spanish co-production is a dance film within a dance film which blurs the lines between rehearsal, real life and performance. Set in Buenos Aires, the film’s slender plot centres on the creative processes of a womanising, middle-aged director who, whilst recovering from a marriage breakup, decides to make a musical centred on the tango. Bearing a close resemblance to the protagonist in Fellini’s “8 1/2” the director dwells on his childhood memories, middle-aged regret and wounded heart as he prepares his film. With only the thinnest of narrative threads linking scenes and moments together, the film relies far more heavily on colour, movement and music than on dialogue or characterisation. The bulk of the film is devoted to expertly-choreographed performances which explore both the fictional director’s personal demons and moments in Argentinian history. Stunningly photographed by Vittorio Storaro. Cast: Miguel Angel Sola, Cecilia Narova, Mia Maestro, Juan Carlos Copes, Carlos Rivarola. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Tanglewood Music School and Music Festival
results.creator_credit: MPO Productions and United States Information Service
results.brief_description: A record of the pioneering work being done by Serge Koussevitsky in establishing the music festival and summer school held each year at Berkshire, USA. With the assistance of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, such composers as Leonard Bernstein and Aaron Copland help and stimulate young students of composition in their work. The film concludes with a premier performance of “The Last words of David” by Randall Thompson.

results.title: Tangerine dream
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television and Keri Light
results.brief_description: A pharmaceutical misadventure which takes place in a rainbow laundromat ends with Bonnie (Tania Lacy), and Simon (Ben Mendelsohn) speaking in visionary gibberish as they flash Bonnie’s laundry. They inhabit an indefinable world, between midnight and dawn, within the murky depths of paranoia and ambition.

results.title: Tangents
results.brief_description: Explains that in problems involving right-angled triangles a choice exists between using sine or cosine in the solution. Discusses the use of tangents as a simpler function for solving some problems.

results.title: Tanganyika: new nation
results.creator_credit: British Pathe News and British Information Services
results.brief_description: A record of HRH Prince Philip’s visit to Tanganyika during the Independence celebrations. After arrival in the capital city, Dar es Salaam, the Duke, with the then Prime Minister, Julius Nyerere, is seen attending several events to mark the occasion, including a tattoo and display, the Independence Day Ceremonial, a reception at Government House, and the State Opening of the Tanganyika Parliament.

results.title: Tanaka
results.brief_description: When Mori, a young Japanese man, is sent by his family to Australia to oversee the funeral of his uncle, Hiroshi, he is thrust into a world of cross-cultural love, grief and misunderstanding. Estranged from Hiroshi for many years, Mori and his family are unaware that he was gay and lived with his Australian lover Ron for decades. As he gets to know his uncle for the first time through videos, photographs, and the stories Ron tells him, Mori must now come to terms with this fresh knowledge and find a way to fulfil his traditional obligations to his family while remaining true to his uncle’s spirit. A powerful and poignant film. Winner of Best Australian Short, Melbourne Queer Film Festival 2003. Cast includes Morihiko Hasebe, Ronald Jacobson, Chris Bartlett, Ant Keogh, Rohan Timlock, Takuji Hasebe, Yukio Kimura.

results.title: Tamworth 88: the Bicentennial Country Music Festival
results.creator_credit: John Begley, BAL Marketing, 9/6 Cinema Factory, 8 Television Tamworth, Taree and Tim Halpin
results.brief_description: Documentary music video covering the highlights of the 1988 Tamworth Bicentennial Country Music Festival including the 16th Australasian Country Music Awards. Tamworth is the country music capital of Australia and each year the music festival attracts country music fans from one end of Australia to the other with over fifty music performers and entertainers. Some of those music stars include Slim Dusty, Johnny Chester, Smokey Dawson, James Blundell, Ted Egan, Eric Bogle and John Williamson with his classic “True Blue”. Hosted by Bill Morrison and Keven Knapp.

results.title: Tamu - the guest
results.creator_credit: Ian Stocks, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Jane Oehr
results.brief_description: A docudrama about the island of Bali as observed by the Australian painter, Donald Friend, who has lived there for six years. Examines the influences of the environment and local art forms on Friend’s work, and the way he interacts with local Balinese society.
